awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Novel System for Uniform Preload in Bolted Joints
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of an improved bolt tightening technology applicable to a wide variety of industries including renewable, power generation, transportation, and infrastructure. The basic bolt-tightening method utilizing a torque-wrench has remained largely unchanged since the introduction of the modern fastener in the 1800s. This results in a preload variation of up to 30% in a multi-bolt joint. New methods, including preload sensing, reduce this variation down to 15% albeit at a high cost. High preload variation leads to inefficient joints, bolt loosening, bolt rupture, and leakage problems over the joint’s lifetime. The proposed innovation can potentially reduce this variation down to 5%, a significant improvement. Additionally, it allows multi-bolt joint tightening in just two passes compared to the current method of four passes which saves time and labor. Successful implementation of the proposed technology will be beneficial in reducing the cost of energy, in particular, offshore wind which is poised for rapid growth in the US. Additionally, it will help prevent hazardous leakage of joints in the nuclear, petrochemical, and oil and gas industries and prevent vibration loosening of joints in the transportation, infrastructure, and heavy machinery industries.

The proposed technology combines existing, widely used technologies, such as a torque-wrench and ultrasonic bolt tension measurement, with a unique and proprietary computer algorithm. The proposed innovation offers precise control of bolt tensioning, which is essential for the reliability of multi-bolt flange joints. The fundamental concept is already proven through high-fidelity simulations. In Phase I research, simulation studies will continue on more realistic multi-bolt joints to further validate the algorithm. The primary goal of Phase I research is the experimental validation and optimization of the proposed algorithm. Extensive testing will be conducted on a scaled-down flange joint with the help of ultrasonic preload sensors. The secondary goal is the development of a minimum viable product concept based on this system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
• Using computer simulations, we were able to prove the technical viability of the proposed concept.
  • We carried out extensive experimental validation of the proposed concept. The experiments further confirmed the viability of the proposed concept.
  • Throughout phase 1, we continued the customer discovery process with a dedicated team member. The feedback from the industry is that the ultrasonic instrumentation needs to match the capability of the Endeavos algorithm and bolt tightening process. Ultrasonic bolt preload sensing technology has come a long way since the 1980s but it is still highly dependent on the user's skill and susceptible to measurement inaccuracies. Based on this, it was concluded that we need to pivot the commercialization effort towards improvement in sensing technologies. This unfortunately requires a complete change in R&D effort going forward.
  • We sought the help of the Innovation Law Center (ILC) at the Syracuse University College of Law, NY to carry out a thorough patent search to check the novelty, usefulness, non-obviousness as well as proper disclosure. This search indicated that the proposed technology can be patented if the proposed algorithm is combined with the unique tightening process and the integrated wrench-sensor concept

1          Technical & Cost Challenges Challenges

In phase 1, thorough computational and experimental validation of the Endeavos algorithm was carried out. The results so far indicate that this concept is novel and very precise but depends on accurate and repeatable preload sensing. Ultrasonic sensing is most appropriate for onsite use since it is non-invasive with high accuracy up to the nearest ?5% in lab settings. Ultrasonic bolt elongation instruments are being used for bolt inspection in wind turbines on a limited basis and by highly trained individuals. This makes it difficult to use off-the-shelf equipment by bolting technicians. This is the primary feedback we received during our customer discovery interviews regarding our proposed solution. Here is a breakdown of key factors that prohibit the immediate application of this technology:

1.1.1         Usage inaccuracies:

  1. Voids in the couplant and variability in the couplant gap height. The couplant is a fluid between the ultrasonic transducer and the bolt to maximize the sonic energy in the bolt. The voids happen due to the method of placing couplant fluid on the bolt head by the end user. Currently, this is carried out manually so it is highly user-dependent.
  2. The ultrasonic transducer placement pressure is another factor that causes variability. If the magnetic transducer is used, then constant pressure can be maintained. However, initial manual placement can cause variability even with constant magnetic pressure.
  3. Accurate placement position and orientation of the ultrasonic transducer on the bolt head. The transducer needs to be placed in the same position (x,y,z) and angle  on each bolt. Manual placement is always susceptible to variation.

1.1.2         UT instrument inaccuracies:

  1. Variability of stress along the bolt affects the consistency of sonic velocity.
  2. Interference of wave paths through the bolt. The state-of-the-art ultrasonic instrument depends on the operator's skill to browse through the signals and find the shortest path. This process needs to be automated by utilizing software and improved post-processing algorithms.

1.1.3         Fastener imperfections:

  1. The sonic velocity is sensitive to the elasticity modulus and density of the bolt which is not well controlled by the bolt manufacturers. This causes variation in UT measurements.
  2. The non-uniformity of residual stress is a challenge for the calibration of the sonic velocity due to the acoustoelastic effect.
  3. Raised grade markings and dished ends can cause the surface to be non-readable.
  4. Bent bolts and nonparallel surfaces.

2.1       Potential Solutions

The consensus from the industry (see section 2.3) is that the technical focus should now be on improving the sensing inaccuracies listed above. Here is a list of potential solutions:

  1. We propose a fixture that places the transducer accurately and holds the couplant in place to solve those issues.
  2. We propose an improvement to the elongation extraction algorithm to automatically calculate the correct length.
  3. Machining the end surfaces of manufactured bolts adds to the cost. We propose manufacturing the bolts to the ultrasonic specifications from the start to avoid the cost increase due to aftermarket machining.

The overall outcome of this research effort is that to proceed forward with bringing a commercially viable uniform bolting technology to the market, we need to pivot towards improving the ultrasonic transducer. Off-the-shelf ultrasonic equipment such as Resonic is state of the art but yet incapable of repeatable results due to operator skill required.
